Description: Rim sherd of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; part of lotus flower in added white outline with added red centre above two faded white bands; exterior: broken maeander pattern between black bands at rim; below, painted decoration consisting possibly of part of a boar’s head with snout pressed against another animal's rump with red and reserved patches, to right; large rosette as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a light-walled, but big, chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice kraters. In this instance, however, the thickness of the sherd suggests that the vessel was not necessarily large and thick-walled. Chalices in this group also display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 90, p. 258, no. 477)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0411) (phase 2)
